;Weng Tongwen (1915-1999) was born in Taishun, Zhejiang. In 1935, he was admitted to the History Department of Tsinghua University and was taught by professors such as Yu Pingbo, Chen Yinke, Qian Mu, and Jin Yuelin. In 1948, he went to study in the UK. In 1955, he was invited by the French sinologist Bai Lege to assist in the "Song History Research Project" and write "The Births, Deaths and Chronology of Figures in the Song Dynasty". Since then, he has served as professor in the Chinese Department of Ruhr University Bonn in Germany, the Department of Oriental Languages ​​at the University of Wisconsin in the United States, the Nanyang University in Singapore, and the History Department at Soochow University in Taiwan. Published include "Chinese Science and Technology History Series", "Yilin Congkao", "Siku Synopsis Supplement", etc.

;

; Mr. Weng Tongwen is an internationally renowned scholar of Chinese literature and history. His academic fields include not only the traditional four-part study, but also social history, literary history, and cultural history. He is well known to the world for his outstanding achievements and widespread influence in many fields, such as history of art, history of science and technology. I entered school late, and due to the cross-strait barrier, I didn’t get to know him, which I regret very much. Recently, a meeting was held in Taishun to commemorate Mr. Weng to discuss Mr. Weng's achievements. After a brief review of Professor Wu Songdi's two huge volumes of works, I can't help but admire him. What is particularly admirable is that Mr. Weng cared about his hometown in his later years and donated a lot of money. Later scholars in the country did not forget his kindness. They published anthologies and commemorated discussions, which are enough to make good stories.

;

; Mr. Weng and I have not had the opportunity to ask for advice in person, and there are few points of intersection in our academic fields. I feel that Mr. Weng Tongwen’s nostalgia for boxing and his academic merits , I am also grateful for Professor Wu Songdi’s enthusiastic invitation, and the organizer of Taishun is motivated by the desire to advance and promote academics. However, I am occasionally troubled by trivial matters and am unable to advance. I would like to write down my rough experience after reading "The Collected Works of Weng Tongwen" . A little bit of petal incense is used to pay homage to the former philosopher.

;

;1. "Supplement to the Siku Synopsis": traditional reading notes with high spirits

;

; Let me first talk about the philological research that I am more familiar with. , take the fifth volume of the anthology, "Supplements to Siku Synopsis" as an example. The eighty-eight articles in this part are written according to the traditional bibliographic and postscript method. Most of them are relatively simple and record the correction of errors found in "Siku Synopsis". Some of them show the depth of effort. The first article examines the three volumes of Guo Zhongshu's "Peijin" in the early Song Dynasty. It discusses the summary and quotes Zhongshu's biography from "History of the Song Dynasty". It is believed that the summary quoted is very different from the popular Baiji version and the palace version "History of the Song Dynasty". It is speculated that the two There was originally a rift in the shogunate of Liu Yun, Duke of Xiangyin, and the target was misunderstood. Then based on the surviving documents of the Five Dynasties and the early Song Dynasty, Guo Zhongshu's life was restored, Daduan was restored, and he criticized Zhongshu for being a "drinker and irresponsible person who had many disobediences with others". He also revealed what Wang Guowei had studied and later engraved the "Nine Classics Characters". It was written by Zhongshu, and his contribution is indescribable. Today, people have a lot to say about the eight volumes of the four-storey version of "The Biography of Talented Scholars of the Tang Dynasty" written by Xin Wenfang of the Yuan Dynasty. Weng Kao has a particularly valuable historical material, that is, it is revealed that the second volume of "Shitian Collection" written by Ma Zuchang of the Yuan Dynasty contains "Ti Xinliang Shi "Pisha Collection"": "If you can't sort through the sand, there will be too much gold. The meaning of modern and ancient times is short and short. Long song. Autumn plugs sing frost armor, spring houses cut paintings, chanting turns the remaining hair, desolate is Yin He." Mr. Weng therefore knew Xin You's "Collection of Poems on Peeling Sand", and commented: "Yin He, Yin Keng, He Xun is also . Compared with this, it is profound, and there is no doubt that he is as famous as Wang Zhiqian and others, and Yang Zai and others advocated peace with them." ">;("Collected Works" mislabeled this passage as Ma Zu Changyu); This is very important for understanding the poetry level and achievements of Xin Wenfang himself, who worked most diligently on the poets of the Tang Dynasty in the Yuan Dynasty. A study of Zhang Tangying's "Shu 梼杌" in the Song Dynasty shows that the original book must have been in ten volumes. The whole article is only over 200 words long and contains extremely rich information, so you can rely on it for basic judgments. There are five volumes of "Luoyang Jialan Ji", and the biographical annotations are all mixed into the main text. Since the Qing Dynasty, many scholars have hoped to separate out the annotations as Quanzu Wangxiao's "Shui Jing Zhu" did. Tang Yan's "Gou Shen", recent scholars Fan Xiangyong's "College Notes", Zhou Zumo's "College Notes" and Xu Gaoruan's "Republication" believe that Xu Shu "learned from various schools and came from behind", but did not add annotations to historical events. In this regard, it is known that Fan and Zhoujia have "profound skills" and the attached pictures are "sufficient for reference." This has gone far beyond the revision and supplement of "Siku Synopsis". In five or six hundred words, one can read the gains and losses of modern people's governance of "Jialan Ji". Since the publication of the abstract, Yu Jiaxi's "Diagnosis of Syndrome" has been particularly famous, and his scholarship has paid special attention to the collected works of the Song and Yuan Dynasties, which can supplement the author's actions and the beginning and end of the original book. Mr. Weng Tongwen also paid attention to the historical events between the Song and Yuan Dynasties. He discussed various articles with Yu, such as the life story of Ye Zhi, the author of "Ai Rizhai Congchao", and the article in "Xijing Miscellaneous Notes" quoted Lao Gan and Hong Ye, The remaining books are unknown. Wang Chen was the author of "Tang Yulin". There are many inventions in the remaining books. Mr. Weng Tongwen even read Su Shi's "Wang Danian's Lament" written for Chen's father. He also knew that Chen came from a maternal relative's house and was a cousin to Shen. , Chen is older than Shen. There are so many wonderful things like this that it is impossible to list them all.

;

;;

;

;In 1936, Weng Tongwen (first from left) was with his family in Xi'an.

;

;2. Research on Publishing History: China’s Contribution from a Western Academic Perspective

;

; "Research on the History of Science, Technology and Culture" Part 3 of "Collected Works of Weng Tongwen" ", there are twenty-one surviving articles, one of which talks about silkworm breeding, eleven on the history of publishing, two on the custom of sitting on chairs, one on the history of gunpowder, one on the incorruptibility of Han corpses, and one on It talks about the observations of genetic phenomena by people in the Tang Dynasty, and the other four articles talk about social and cultural exchanges between China and foreign countries, covering a wide range of topics. The most direct impression is that Mr. Weng is a traditional scholar who has read many Chinese books in depth. However, because he has studied and taught in the West for a long time, his research interests and narrative stance are fundamentally different from those of traditional scholars. Whether he reads common books or Xi Jian's books all have unique insights and revelations, numerous discoveries, solid evidence, and new and reliable conclusions. These are the common characteristics of this group of papers.

;

; Let’s talk about the history of publishing first. From writing to publishing, the Tang Dynasty was a critical period. Exactly when the earliest engravings began has been debated among bibliophiles. Due to the discovery of Dunhuang posthumous documents and new documents, the earliest publication was probably in Shuzhong during the Yizong period. As for the scriptures found in South Korea with Empress Wu's new characters, the exact date of publication is still controversial. The articles written by Mr. Weng Tongwen were written at different times, but they involve more detailed interpretations and discovery of documents. Here is a summary, which is very enlightening to read. "Correct Interpretation of the Word "Mule" in Yuan Zhen's Writings Intertwined with the History of Printing" is a large article that analyzes it from a small perspective. In December of the fourth year of Changqing reign of Yuanzhen, he wrote the "Preface to the Collection of Baishi Changqing". There is a self-note: "Yang and Yuejian wrote many calligraphy models of Le Tian and Yu's miscellaneous poems, which were sold in shops." Hu Zhenheng of the Ming Dynasty also wrote It is believed that "Mule" refers to engraving and printing. In modern times, Hu Shi advocated Youli, and then there were as many as 20 or 30 writers. Only three people such as Xiang Da expressed their opposition, thinking that "Mule" refers to double-line hooks to draw white. Reproduction technology of ink marks on poetry manuscripts. Mr. Weng agreed with Xiang and analyzed the interpretation and changes of the two words in the past dynasties from the etymology and word formation, hoping that future researchers will no longer be troubled by this word. His argumentation process was extremely rigorous, and he had two unexpected gains. First, he compared the word "mo" with the words "mo", "motuo", "motuo", "mole", and "moji" that have appeared successively since the Eastern Han Dynasty. They must all be the same. "The technique of making copies on paper according to the original pattern of writing strokes or ink marks." The second is to prove that "mule" is a new term that appeared in the mid-Tang Dynasty. This argument may seem trivial, but it actually resolves the ambiguity in the interpretation of a large number of documents related to engraving issues in the Middle Ages, and the conclusion is fully credible.

;

; "The earliest self-engraved poetry collection was Chen Yong, a native of Shu in the late Tang Dynasty". It is not long, but it is very interesting. "Si Ku Yuan Jiu" identifies the person who first engraved a collection of poems as Qian Shu Guanxiu, whose disciple Tanyu's "Preface to the Collection of Chanyue" says: "Then I searched for and inspected the collection of poems and secretly memorized about a thousand poems, which were carved into a volume. The title is "Collection of Chanyue." This preface was written in the fifth year of Qiande in the former Shu Dynasty ;(923);, and it is clear that there is no Disagreement. Ye Dehui's "Shu Lin Qing Hua" according to the "Old History of the Five Dynasties - He Ning Biography" states that "there are hundreds of volumes collected, self-sealed on the board, hundreds of seals printed, and benefits distributed to others", which lists his events before Guanxiu. Mr. Weng believes that He Ning is later than Guan Xiu, and there is no absolute date for the engraving of his books, so he disagrees. He uncovered a neglected record from "Beimeng Suoyan", that is, Chen Yong, a Jinshi during the reign of Emperor Zhaozong, had a pair of lines at the beginning of his poem: "Buffaloes on the other side cross with their noses floating on their noses, and sandbirds nod their way along the stream." Taoist priest Du Guangting Questioned, these two sentences are not good, "Why should this be the beginning of the volume?" Chen Yong replied: "It was once rewarded by the nobles, so it is engraved on the beginning of the volume." Mr. Weng revealed this article, which is of course very valuable and should be able to supplement the previous ones. A case study of Shu engraved poetry collection. Whether the absolute date is earlier than Guanxiu can be discussed again.

;

; "The earliest publisher in world history appeared in Chang'an in the middle and late Tang Dynasty", first based on Dunhuang documents, it was confirmed that there was a person selling almanacs in the second year of Emperor Xizong's reign in the late Tang Dynasty. The Fan Shang family in Chengdu and the Bian family in Longchifang, Chengdu County, which sold Buddhist mantras, are all mentioned in the discussions of Zhang Xiumin, Li Shuhua, and Qian Cunxun. Chen Zuolong, a bookseller in Chang'an, has passed the examination of two calligraphers surnamed Li. Mr. Weng even cited the example of Bo 2633's "Mrs. Cui's Training of Women", although it was a banknote version, but there was no "printed version of the Li family in Shangdu" at the end, so it was written based on the printed version. I have read this volume again and again. The so-called "Praise to Bai Shilang" is definitely named after Bai Juyi, and the work may not have been published during Bai Juyi's lifetime. The second is Bo's 2675 reverse note of "New Collection of Emergency Moxibustion Sutra", which has the characters "Seal of the Li family in Beijing in Dongshi" at the end. Although it can be inferred to be after the second year of Xiantong, it is also very precious. The third one is a printed copy of the Si 8010 residual calendar, with the cross "Shangdu Shi Dongshi Dadaojia seal" at the end, which is considered to belong to a bookstore or publisher with "Da Dao" as its inscription.

;

; In the two articles about movable type printing, in addition to researching Bi Sheng's invention of clay movable type printing stated in Shen Kuo's "Mengxi Bi Tan", Mr. Weng vigorously pursued Bi Sheng His real life and what inspired his clay movable type skills. Particularly exciting among them are "the doubts caused by clay type and its efficiency issues" and "the reason why movable type could not replace engraving before the late Qing Dynasty". The former, based on bits and pieces of records, shows that Bi Sheng had several projects in succession in the two hundred years after Bi Sheng. Several attempts were made, but there was no big development. Mr. Weng’s explanation for this is that although Bi Sheng was the first to invent movable type, there was no inheritance of movable type in the future. Instead, everyone kept starting from scratch and never overcame the shortcomings of the crude and rough movable type. Although China invented movable type printing, it did not replace woodblock printing. Fundamental changes did not occur until Western technology was introduced. "Supplementary Discussion on the Invention of European Movable Type Plate Also Induced by Engraving Printing" examines the way Europeans experimented with printing techniques before Gutenberg in Germany promoted the principle of movable type in the 15th century. In particular, he saw that the high frequency of letter engraving made it easier for Westerners to get ideas. Chinese woodblock printing methods inspired Europeans even more prominently. Although there are many speculations in this article, the basic insights are still within a reasonable range, and what I see is quite reasonable.

;

; In addition, the study of the life and book engraving career of Chen Qi, a descendant of Wu Zhao from the Later Shu Dynasty, the Xiangtai Yue family of the Southern Song Dynasty, and the book printer, are also included. They are all important and key figures in the history of Chinese printing. It is interesting to read clearly. "Printing reduces the cost of books by nine-tenths" is also an interesting topic. What I am more interested in is the interesting story at the end of the article about the fairy Wu Cailuan's book "Tang Yun". Mr. Weng continued the opinion of Taiwanese scholar Wang Meng'ou and believed that Wu Cailuan's "Tang Yun" was hidden in the National Palace Museum in Taipei. He always regretted not being able to see it in person. According to Zhou Zumo's "Collection of Yun Shu of the Tang and Five Dynasties" ; (Zhonghua Book Company);, this volume is stored in the Palace Museum in Beijing and was photocopied by Zhou After reading the complete version, it was concluded that it was the Tang Dynasty Pei Wuqi's orthographic version of "Public Mistakes, Filling the Gap and Qie Yun", not Sun Wei's "Tang Yun". As for the book written by the female fairy Wu Cailuan, it is only a beautiful legend caused by the inscription and postscript of Xiang Yuanbian of the Ming Dynasty, and cannot be taken as true.

;

;;

;

;In the 1950s, Weng Tongwen (first from right) was in France with his friends.

;

;3. Science and Technology Life History Research: Daily and Important Perspectives

;

; Regarding life history, Mr. Weng Tongwen talks about the origin of chairs in China These two magnificent articles are examined in the context of global human history. They not only draw on the insights of Chinese and foreign scholars, but also extensively quote rich material objects obtained from literature and archaeology, and strive to restore the Chinese people from sitting low or kneeling to gradually sitting high. The process, including the "Chronological Record of Rope Bed Materials", covers a period of more than 700 years. It mentions six chairs that appeared east of Congling from the Jin Dynasty to the end of the Six Dynasties. Five of them originated from India, which further proves that the chairs were introduced from India via the Silk Road. He also came to the same conclusion when he investigated the special-shaped rope beds of chairs, and proved that most of them were related to monks and monasteries. He pointed out that the rope bed was a tool for monks to meditate and meditate, and some monks developed the habit of not lying down day and night throughout their lives, and most of them He sat on the rope bed. After the Middle Tang Dynasty, he examined the traces of chairs entering the palace and scholar's homes, and explained that chairs also led to an increase in the height of other furniture, such as tables, tall cabinets, etc.

;

; Mr. Weng talked about the era when the book "The Synopsis of Zhenyuan Miaodao" was written. Based on the mention of Yanluozi in the book, it is suspected that it was written in the middle and late Five Dynasties. . I quoted the general rules of Taoist discussion from Taoist books, and felt that it was more likely to be written in the Song Dynasty. Based on the experience of the Waidan family, the article believes that incendiary gunpowder weapons began in the Song Dynasty, and the emergence of firecrackers should be after Song Renzong. The general conclusion can be believed.

;

; "Three Interlocking Inventions Traced to Silk Production Techniques" is the first and most important article in this part, so I I’ll introduce it at the end. China is a large agricultural country, and there has been a tradition of men farming and women weaving since ancient times. This article will explain that China's three great inventions (referring to printing, gunpowder, magnets) or four great inventions (the first three plus papermaking) have certain logic in themselves. His opinion is: 1. The discovery of the use of silk The invention of techniques for breeding silkworms to produce silk and bleaching wadding; 2. Papermaking originated from the imitation of "natural paper" appearing in bleached wadding; 3. Block printing originated from the combination of "printable paper" and "plate lettering"; 4. Movable type printing technology was conceived due to the "phenomenon of discarding undamaged carved boards". Although this does not include all the four great inventions, it well explains the intrinsic reason why only China can pioneer the invention of papermaking and printing.

;

;;

;

;"Collected Works of Weng Tongwen", Zhejiang People's Publishing House, 2019.

;

;4. Standing between tradition and modernity, showing the path for future generations to learn

;

; Finally, I would like to express my gratitude to Mr. Weng Tongwen as the representative Make a brief summary of the academic achievements and characteristics of the older generation of scholars. Mr. Weng Tongwen is a generation of scholars born in the early Republic of China, and his research path continued until the end of the twentieth century. When he was born, the Qing Dynasty was already dead, but he was proficient in the four classics, based on the Classics, and enriched with poetry. He took notes because of his gains in reading, and concentrated on writing papers based on his experiences. This is a traditional academic method. There are still lingering thoughts. However, the trend since the early Republic of China has strongly advocated using Western learning to explore the path of national salvation and development, and has also led humanities scholars to strive to accept Western academic approaches and explore various new academic topics related to life and society that the sages often ignored. Mr. Weng Tongwen was initially educated at Southwest Associated University, Yunnan University and St. John's University. He studied and worked in Britain, France, Germany, the United States, New Zealand and other countries, and finally served in universities in Taiwan. His studies are rooted in tradition, and his vision and methods are deeply influenced by Western studies. He combines literature with cultural relics to fully integrate society and life. He pays special attention to the lower society, special skills and basic classics. As mentioned above in this article, there are less than a hundred articles in the "Sikubiaoyao Supplement". The long ones are more than a thousand words, and the short ones are only a hundred words. However, what they say must contain new insights and maintain a high spirit. It is a reference to the sayings of many famous writers in modern times. , all with outspoken comments. Articles on the history of life, science and technology, and publishing history can also exhaust the literature, refer to the sages of the times, analyze the subtle ideas, invent new insights, cite abundantly, be cautious in speaking, have clear opinions, and write well. Being peaceful can fully reflect everyone's style and can show the path for future generations to follow.
